Direct  beneficiaries  of  the  Project  are  about  148,000  children 
between  birth  and  8  years  of  age  in  the  12  poorest  raions.  In 
addition,  support  for  immunization  will  benefit  all  infants  in  the 
country.  The  Project  will  directly  enhance  the  development  of 
children and their future productivity.  

The  Project  will  improve  the  effectiveness  and  efficiency  of  child 
development  services.  Some  services  in  the  health  sector  have 
been unable to achieve their full potential due to gaps in training 
and irregular supply of essential drugs. By bridging the gaps, the 
Project  will  improve  the  effectiveness  of  existing  services  at 
minimal  additional  cost.  The  Project  will  also  improve  the  cost-
efficiency  of  early  education  programs  by  introducing  alternative 
community-based  models  to  complement  formal  preschools,  and 
improving child care at home.  

The  Project  will  build  the  capacity  of  the  AOs  and  communities. 
Many project activities will be implemented at the community level 
and  managed  by  AOs.  This  focus  on  AOs  and  communities  will 
improve  governance  by  bringing  activities  closer  to  the  intended 
beneficiaries,  and  facilitate  the  achievement  of  project  objectives 
by providing–through a village initiative fund–opportunities for the 
communities  to  design  and  implement  activities  that  meet  their 
needs.  

The  Project  involves  almost  no  technical  risk.  The  selected 
interventions have been tested and proven effective in the Kyrgyz 
Republic and internationally. The most significant challenge will be  
effective  implementation  through  multiple  ministries  and  central 
and local government  bodies. A steering committee consisting of 
experienced  representatives  of  concerned  ministries  and  oblasts 
(provinces) has been established and will provide policy guidance 
to the Project. The Project provides for substantial training of AO 
representatives and assistance of the child and family coordinator 
during the first 2 years of project implementation. 
 
Another  challenge  is  sustainability  of  the  services  after  the 
completion of the Project. Maintaining the quality of primary health 
care and preschool programs will require predictable, timely, and 
adequate budget allocations. Recurrent costs will be about 1% of 
the national health and education budget. The Project will ensure 
that  the  Government  develops  sustainability  plans  for  vaccines 
and essential drugs, which are the major needed supplies.

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

Young  children  suffer  most  in  times  of  economic  contraction.  International  research 
2. 
shows that poverty has measurable detrimental effects on children’s physical growth, cognitive 
capacity, and psychosocial adjustment. The long-term impacts of these effects are most severe 
when  children  are  unprotected  during  the  years  before  they  enter  school.  Targeted  programs 
that  integrate  health,  nutrition,  and  education/care  for  young  children  offset  the  deleterious 
effects  of  poverty.  Without  targeted  interventions,  the  majority  of  children  in  poverty  will 
experience inadequate development in their early years, permanently diminishing their capacity 
to achieve their potential.   
 
3. 
The  Kyrgyz  Republic  has  a  population  of  5  million,  about  22%  of  whom  are  below  8 
years  of  age.  The  per  capita  income  is  about  $300,  the  second  lowest  among  Central  Asian 
countries,  and  poverty  is  prevalent.  According  to  the  National  Statistical  Committee,  40%  and 
47% of the population live in poverty in urban and rural areas, respectively. The health, nutrition, 
and education sectors have direct impacts on the lives of young children in poor families. These 
sectors  were  funded  centrally  during  the  former  Soviet  Union  (FSU)  and,  until  its  final  years, 
were relatively protected. The Kyrgyz Republic had achieved a high level of education and had 
developed  extensive  education  and  health  care  networks  before  independence.  However, 
budgets,  coverage,  and  quality  of  services  have  declined  in  recent  years.  Rural  and  urban 
disparities  are  widening.  Scarce  resources  are  concentrated  in  the  major  cities  and  towns; 
training and supplies reach remote, impoverished rural health posts and schools last.

6. 
Children’s nutrition status has deteriorated since independence. In addition to a general 
increase  in  poverty,  the  reduced  availability  of  food  subsidies  targeted  at  children  and  meals 
formally  provided  through  preschools  has  eliminated  key  nutrition  sources  for  young  children. 
The  collapse  of  the  production  and  distribution  of  fortified  food  has  increased  micronutrient 
deficiency.  According  to  DHS,  the  prevalence  of  stunting,  which  is  highly  correlated  with 
reduced cognitive performance, reached 29% and 30% in Osh and Naryn oblasts (provinces), 
respectively. The prevalence of iodine deficiency disorder (IDD) is increasing. The Government 
reports  that  the  number  of  IDD  cases  has  increased  by  8-10  times  in  the  last  10  years. 
International  research  has  clearly  and  consistently  demonstrated  that  an  average  of  13  IQ 
points is lost in iodine-deficient children living in areas where goiter is endemic.2 Iron deficiency 
anemia  (IDA)  is  also  highly  prevalent:  48.5%  of  children  below  3  years  of  age  and  38%  of 
women  were  anemic  in  1997.  Women  with  IDA  face  a  higher  risk  of  pregnancy-related 
complications  that  contribute  to  higher  maternal  mortality  ratio.  Mothers  with  IDA  give  birth  to 
infants whose psychomotor and cognitive skills are diminished or developmentally delayed.  The 
school performance of children with IDA, is also affected. Among adults, productivity losses due 
to  IDA  have  been  estimated  at  5-17%  depending  on  the  kind  of  work.  Overall,  micronutrient 
malnutrition in developing countries costs at least a 5% loss of gross domestic product.3 
 
7. 
Many  young  children  have  not  benefited  from  psychosocial  development  opportunities 
and  primary  school  dropouts  are  increasing.  Prior  to  independence,  preschool  institutions 
comprising full-day nurseries and kindergartens offered a package of child nutrition, health, and 
education  services  free  of  charge  to  more  than  a  third  of  preschool-age  children.  However, 
many  preschool  institutions  have  been  closed down.  Rural  areas  are  especially  hard  hit.  Only 
one  third  of  operating  preschools  are  located  in  rural  areas.  The  surviving  preschools  have 
started  charging  small  fees  to  compensate  for  reduced  state  support  and  have  become 
unaffordable to poor children. In 2000, only 7.1%, 3.6%, and 2.3% of preschool-age children in 
Jalal-abad,  Osh,  and  Naryn,  respectively,  attended  preschool.  Parents  have  not  been  able  to 
replace  the  functions  of  preschools.  Parents  in  rural  areas  lack  knowledge  of  child  care 
practices to stimulate children’s psychosocial development, and have little time or inclination to 
communicate or play with their children. A study conducted during Project preparation revealed 
that many young children in the Kyrgyz Republic are left unattended for most of the day. Four- 
year olds were with some caretaker only for 5 hours a day and spend the rest of the day alone.  
 
Before,  extensive  preschool  coverage  resulted  in  children  joining  the  formal  school 
8. 
system already able to read and write. In contrast, most children now enter grade 1 unprepared 
either academically or socially. The average age at school entry has declined: in 1991, 27,200 
6-year-olds entered grade 1, and in 1999, 40,000 did. This suggests that grade 1 is increasingly 
serving as kindergarten and a school preparation class. The result is added pressure on grade 1

completion rate is only 85%. This lower-than-expected completion rate is at least partly due to

The condition of poor young children and their families and deteriorating public services 
9. 
for children require effective early childhood development (ECD) programs. Investment in ECD 
benefits not only children and their families, but also society as a whole. Society benefits from 
greater productivity in later life. Investment in ECD can reduce the needs for and cost of future 
social  welfare  programs,  and  public  expenditures  in  the  health  care  system.  Children  who 
benefit  from  health  and  nutrition  interventions  and  preschool  experiences  are  more  likely  to 
enroll  and  persist  in  school,  to  be  healthier,  to  need  fewer  social  protection  or  criminal  justice 
services,  and  to  earn  higher  incomes  as  adults.  Research  shows  a  positive  correlation  of  ill 
health  as  a  child,  with  physical  impairments  and  health  problems  later  in  life,  all  of  which  are 
burdens on health services. ECD also addresses an important societal concern of equity. ECD 
has larger impacts on deprived children than better-off children and contributes to narrowing the 
differences  in  development  at  the  beginning  of  life  among  children  of  various  economic 
backgrounds.  This  is  especially  important  for  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  and  other  FSU  countries 
where economic inequality is widening.  
 
10. 
ECD also has positive impacts on women, especially mothers, since mothers and child 
health are closely intertwined. Improvements in child health results in less time needed to care 
for sick children and reduced costs of health care. Aside from the obvious benefits of improved 
health  for  both  mothers  and  children,  ECD  interventions,  especially  increased  availability  of

 Child  Health.    According  to  Government  data,  the  major  causes  of  infant  deaths  are 
acute respiratory infections and diarrhea–diseases that were responsible for 38.2% and 12.4% 
of all infant deaths in 2001. Causes of under-five deaths follow the same pattern. Child deaths 
due to these diseases can be prevented by quality primary health care. In the Kyrgyz Republic, 
primary  health  care  providers  consist  of  FAPs  (primary  health  care  posts)  and  Family  Group 
Practices  (FGPs).  FAPs  have  feldshers  (primary  health  care  workers)  and  midwives  and  are 
often  the  only  health  care  providers  located  in  remote  villages.  FGPs  have  medical  doctors  in 
place.  They  provide  primary  health  care  services  to  people  and  supervise  the  FAPs.  While 
FGPs  have  received  assistance  under  other  projects  in  recent  years,  FAPs  have  been 

 4 

neglected. Therefore, to reduce child mortality in rural areas, improving the FAPs will be crucial. 
Immunization  is  arguably  the  most  important  means  to  prevent  infant  deaths.  The  Kyrgyz 
Republic has maintained universal immunization for children, relying on vaccines funded by the 
Government  of  Japan  and  the  Global  Alliance  for  Vaccines  and  Immunization.  However,  this 
assistance is due to end in 2004. Given its fiscal constraints, the Government will need interim 
financial  support  to  sustain  universal  immunization.  The  Integrated  Management  of  Childhood 
Illnesses (IMCI) program was developed by WHO and UNICEF to efficiently reduce the severity 
of major childhood illnesses and deaths due to illnesses among children less than 5 years old. 
IMCI has been piloted in three raions, but not on a large scale for lack of resources.

Child Nutrition. The most effective means to prevent IDD and IDA is to promote use of 
iodized  salt  and  iron  fortification  of  staple  food.4  Since  2001,  ADB  has  been  administering  a 
Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  (JFPR)  project  for  improving  nutrition  of  women  and 
children.5 The Project has contributed to production of iodized salt and iron-fortified wheat flour 
of  good  quality,  enforcement  of  the  universal  salt  iodization  law,  and  increased  public 
awareness  of  the  importance  of  using  iodized  salt  and  fortified  food.  The  Government 
introduced  the  National  Program  for  Reduction  of  IDD  for  2003-2007  (approved  9  December 
2002)  to  accelerate  actions  to  prevent  IDD.  The  main  objectives  of  the  program  are  to  (i) 
achieve compulsory salt iodate fortification and refortification; (ii) increase the percentage of the 
population  consuming  iodized  salt  to  95%;  (iii)  prevent  industrial  salt  use  for  human 
consumption;  (iv)  conduct  social  mobilization  for  IDD  prevention;  and  (v)  train  primary  health 
care providers on IDD prevention, diagnosis and treatment.

priority  of  the  Government  Strategy  on  Education  Development  to  2010.  The  number  of 
preschools  will  be  increased  and  the  curriculum  will  be  reformed.  The  FSU  model  of  full-day, 
full-service  nurseries  and  kindergartens  is  expensive  and  beyond  the  financial  means  of  the

updated  and  made  more  child-centered.  Several  alternative  preschool  programs  have  been

preschools,  and  improve  grade  1  teaching.  The  combination  of  increasing  preschool 
opportunities  and  better  grade  1  teaching  will  contribute  not  only  to  children’s  psychosocial 
development  but  also  to  increasing  the  primary  school  completion  rate  and  learning 
achievement.  Even  with increased availability of preschool programs, families will continue to 
be  the  primary  child  care  providers,  and  the  quality  of  child  care  at  home  will  have  significant

Lessons  Learned  and  Special  Features.  The  Project  has  three  distinct  design 
17. 
features:  integrated  ECD,  multisectoral  and  decentralized  implementation,  and  community-
based  interventions.  Health,  nutrition,  and  education  are  interactive  determinants  of  child 
development, and programs to optimize child development should integrate these features. The 
integrated ECD interventions have been found to be more effective than isolated single sector 
interventions. Most ECD interventions by the Government or international organizations remain 
isolated  and  narrowly  focused  pilots,  small  in  scale,  often  covering  only  a  few  raions.  The 
Project will consolidate successful pilot interventions as an integrated package of ECD services, 
take  them  to  scale,  and  coordinate  multiple  agencies  to  achieve  tangible  effects.  The 
experience of ADB-financed ECD projects in the Philippines shows that strong leadership at the 
national  Government  level  is  crucial  in  leading  a  multisectoral  ECD  project,  and  also  that 
activities entrusted to local governments are more likely to progress than those handled by the 
central  government.  The  President’s  office  has  been  selected  to  be  the  Executing  Agency  to 
lead this multisectoral Project and to coordinate different ministries. A substantial part of project 
activities  will  take  place  at  the  ayil  okmotu  (AO,  village  authority)  level.  The  AO  and  the 
community will be entrusted with organizing community-based preschools. AO and community 
initiatives will be supported by providing grants from a village initiative fund (VIF). This model is 
based on a positive experience of the discretionary fund under the ADB-financed Social Service 
Delivery Project in the Kyrgyz Republic.

A. 

Objectives 

The  goal  of  the  Community-Based  Early  Childhood  Development  Project  is  to  improve 
18. 
health, nutrition, and psychosocial development of children between birth and 8 years of age in 
the 12 poorest raions. Specific objectives are to (i) reduce IMR and U5MR, (ii) reduce IDD, (iii) 
reduce  IDA  both  among  children  and  pregnant  women,  and  (iv)  improve  psychosocial 
development of preschool children. The Project will contribute to attaining the MDGs to reduce 
IMR  and  U5MR  and  achieve  universal  primary  education.  The  Project  will  also  contribute  to 
increasing  women’s  economic  opportunities  outside  the  home  by  improving  children’s  health 
and nutrition status, and increasing access to preschool programs.  
 
19. 
The  Project  has  three  components.  The  child  health  and  nutrition  component  will  (i) 
ensure universal coverage and quality of immunization, (ii) improve case management for major 
childhood  morbidities,  (iii)  improve  functioning  of  primary  health  care  posts,  (iv)  universalize 
consumption  of  iodized  salt,  and  (v)  introduce  behavioral  change  to  prevent  IDA.  The  early 
childhood care and education component will (i) improve access of poor children to preschool 
programs  including  state-run  preschools  and  community  preschool  programs,  (ii)  improve  the 
quality  of  grade  1  education,  and  (iii)  improve  the  quality  of  child  care  at  home.  The  capacity 
building component will (i) develop the capacity of local governments and communities to plan, 
implement,  and  monitor  ECD  activities;  and  (ii)  improve  data  collection  and  monitoring  of 
development indicators for young children between birth and 8 years of age from the community 
to the central Government levels.

Early  childhood  development  (ECD)  is  inherently  multisectoral  because  young  children

4. 
The  economic  rationale  for  investing  in  early  childhood  development  (ECD)  is  strong. 
Investment in ECD will improve an individual’s future prospect of earning. The improvement will 
contribute  to  individual  wealth  and  poverty  reduction,  increase  future  productivity  of  the  labor 
force, and lead to economic development. Numerous studies demonstrate that improved health, 
education, and poverty that impact the first several years of children’s development are directly 
related to improved adult and societal productivity. The early years of human life are a critical 
period  during  which  the  foundations  for  healthy  physical,  cognitive,  emotional,  and  social 
development  are  laid.  Neuroscience  has  revealed  the  importance  for  brain  development  of  a 
child’s health, activities, and experiences in the first few years of life. Children who are deprived 
of appropriate stimulation, care, and nutrition during their early years often develop poorly and 
cannot reach their full potential. Although not always impossible, it is very difficult and expensive 
to  alter  the  outcomes  of  this  critical  period  in  later  life.  Some  deficits,  for  example,  iodine  and 
iron deficiency, cause irreversible damage. 
 
5. 
Investment  in  ECD  benefits  not  only  children  and  their  families,  but  also  society  as  a 
whole.  Society  benefits  from  ECD  through  greater  productivity  in  later  life.  The  child  care 
programs  free  up  women  to  work  and  thus  increase  the  availability  of  the  labor  force. 
Investment in ECD is also preventive and can reduce the need for and costs of social welfare

Integrated  Approach.  Health,  nutrition,  education,  and  home  care  are  interactive 
determinants of child outcomes, and therefore programs to optimize child development should 
integrate these features. Experience shows that integrated ECD interventions are more effective 
than  isolated  single  sector  intervention.  Young  children  are  very  susceptible  to  infections  and 
diseases, and this vulnerability is greater when a child is malnourished. Malnutrition, illness, or 
neglect  during  childhood  has  immediate  and  long-term  effects  on  cognitive  development  and 
learning achievement through loss of concentration, apathy, and reduced activity. Children who 
are  malnourished  or  neglected  during  early  childhood  are  more  likely  to  delay  enrollment  in 
primary  school;  they  are  likely  to  perform  less  well  and  to  learn  less  than  well-nourished 
children.

Community-Based Approach. The preschool system in the former Soviet Union was a 
distinctly center-based approach that prevented the involvement of communities and parents in 
child  development,  and  imposed  centrally  planned  standardized  curriculum.  The  center-based 
approach  was  an  expensive  model.  The  existing  state-run  kindergartens  are  not  a  financially 
viable  option  for  endeavor  the  Ministry  of  Education  and  Culture’s  (MOEC)  to  increase  the 
coverage  of  preschool.  The  annual  expenditure  per  child  in  a  kindergarten  in  Jalal-Abad  was

community-based  preschool  programs  introduced  under  the  Project  expects  the  per  child

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in the Krygyz Republic: 
The quality of primary health care and early education, including diagnosis and treatment of chronic illnesses, disease 
and  malnutrition,  provides  the  basis  for  growth  and  development  of  children.  Without  adequate  health  services,  the 
lifetime  opportunities  of  children  may  be  limited  before  the  children  enroll  at  school.  Problems  of  children  are 
compounded in families living in poverty, especially in poor communities. Public investment in better health, nutrition, 
water/sanitation,  and  early  childhood  development  offers  long-term  human  development  benefits.  Reduction  in 
diseases due to iodine deficiencies offers immediate savings in public health expenditure. 

B. 

Poverty Analysis  

Proposed Classification: Core Poverty Intervention 

 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? In 2001,the poor comprised 40% of the population in urban areas, and 47% 
in rural areas, according to the Government national sample expenditure survey. The "social passport" data from the 
Ministry of Labor and Social Protection (MLSP) indicate higher poverty rate based on income data. Analysis of data 
collected during project preparation reveals that larger families are concentrated in rural areas, and that the number of 
children  aged  0-8  are  greater  in  poor  rural  families.  In  addition  to  income  poverty,  analysis  reveals  higher  rates  of 
iodine  deficiency,  anemia,  and  malnutrition  in  rural  communities.  Access  to  primary  health  care  is  reduced  by  lower 
level  of  services,  lack  of  medicines  and  equipment,  and  the  prohibitive  cost  of  travel  to  the  raion  center  for  testing, 
diagnosis, and treatment. Any preschool opportunities outside the raion center are the exception. Small/isolated rural 
communities  lack  both  information  about  health,  nutrition,  and  child  development  as  well  as  the    resources  to  meet 
identified  needs.  The  Project  targets  the  12  poorest  raions  where  poverty  rate  is  above  69%,  and  most  of  the 
interventions cover all eligible children. Therefore, more than 50% of the beneficiaries will be the poor. 

C. 

Participation Process 

 
Stakeholder analysis? National task forces and oblast task groups (raions vs oblasts) have identified services that no 
longer meet standards achieved in former Soviet times. Solutions proposed tended to seek funding to meet the former 
Soviet Union’s standards rather than reviewing needs and the most effective response to need. Participatory dialogue 
stakeholder  opportunities  and  resources  as  well  as  problem  analysis  have  been  completed,  and  new  solutions  are 
developing. 
 
Participation strategy? The proposed project aims at community mobilization, including rapidly assessing needs, and 
identifying  potential  responses,  combined  with  a  Village  Initiative  Fund  giving  communities  some  resources  to 
provide/improve  children’s  services  and  an  incentive  to  make  those  improvements.  Project  will  also  coordinate  the  
community  response  to  identified  needs  and  improve  the  quality  of  basic  health  care,  information  about  hygiene, 
nutrition, and child development, and thus, ensure a better preparation for children entering school. 
 
Contribution  of  the  sector/subsector  to  reduce  poverty  in  the  Krygyz  Republic:  Early  Childhood  Development  (ECD) 
interventions are key to interrupting intergenerational transfer of poverty by building opportunities for and capacities of 
individuals born into poverty.  ECD interventions enable women to work and older girls to attend school. Project will be 
implemented  in  the  poorest  raions,  thus  maximizing  the  effects  of  ECD  interventions,  which  have  the  strongest 
impacts, where participating children are from marginalized and low-income families.
